Anyone who has seen my posting here knows I do not believe that God exists nor that a man named Jesus was the divine son of a Virgin who died for our "Sins" .. However I have for years been fascinated by how easily people believe all of this simply because a book ,which is Questionable at best, Tells them that it is true. One of the things I've always wondered about is the belief that Adam and Eve were the first Man and Woman to exist here on earth. I'm not taking shots at religious people here, I am genuinely interested in this subject and would like the religious faction to explain to me why this belief is , and what led them to believe it so fully that they will go to any lengths to dispute evidence to the contrary. I've asked this of Pastors, priests, and other religious people that I know and I get the same tired answers, most notably that the story in the Bible actually repeats itself, or rather that the men who put the Bible together failed to realize they were telling the same story twice. This is the part I am interested in.....
 
 
 In The First Book, Genesis 1, verses 26-31 It says...
 
 26 And God said, Let us make man in our image, after our likeness: and let them have dominion over the fish of the sea, and over the fowl of the air, and over the cattle, and over all the earth, and over every creeping thing that creepeth upon the earth.
 
 27 So God created man in his [own] image, in the image of God created he him; male and female created he them.
 
 28 And God blessed them, and God said unto them, Be fruitful, and multiply, and replenish the earth, and subdue it: and have dominion over the fish of the sea, and over the fowl of the air, and over every living thing that moveth upon the earth.
 
 29 And God said, Behold, I have given you every herb bearing seed, which [is] upon the face of all the earth, and every tree, in the which [is] the fruit of a tree yielding seed; to you it shall be for meat.
 
 30 And to every beast of the earth, and to every fowl of the air, and to every thing that creepeth upon the earth, wherein [there is] life, [I have given] every green herb for meat: and it was so.
 
 31 And God saw every thing that he had made, and, behold, [it was] very good. And the evening and the morning were the sixth day. 
 
 Now this Clearly states that God Created Man and Woman at the same time, and that he told them to "Go Forth, and Multiply".. Not my words, these are straight from the Bible. It makes no mention of the Name Adam, it makes no mention of Eve, simply says Male and Female he did create. 
 Now lets go a bit further. 
 
 Genesis chapter 2 verses 1 -3 
 
 1Thus the heavens and the earth were finished, and all the host of them.
 
 2And on the seventh day God ended his work which he had made; and he rested on the seventh day from all his work which he had made.
 
 3And God blessed the seventh day, and sanctified it: because that in it he had rested from all his work which God created and made.
 
 Now here we see that Gods work is DONE. He ends his work on the 7th day and took a little break from all the hard work that he had done. Now let's go a little bit further to 
 
 Genesis chapter 2 verse 6-8
 
 6But there went up a mist from the earth, and watered the whole face of the ground.
 
 7And the LORD God formed man of the dust of the ground, and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life; and man became a living soul.
 
 8And the LORD God planted a garden eastward in Eden; and there he put the man whom he had formed. 
 
 
 Now he creates Adam.. and a little later Eve. And also, instead of telling Adam to " Go Forth and Multiply", He makes him a special Garden and places him there, where he is told he can eat anything EXCEPT a certain tree of knowledge. 
 
 Does anyone besides me see the discrepancy here?. Further evidence to support the fact that Adam was NOT the first man can be found as you continue to read Genesis, where Cain is cast out and somehow finds a Wife in a different part of the world whom just happened to be old enough to become his wife. So my question to you religious ones is what is the meaning of all this? is this two separate accounts of creation told in the same chapter?. or is this a parable or Fairy tale made up by a confused old man named Moses? I'd like to hear some legitimate explanations if you will.

 You belch and your yahoo cohorts lap it up. You folks are true novices.
 
 It is often claimed that Genesis 1 and 2 contain two different creation-narratives. In point of fact, however, the strictly complementary nature of the “two” accounts is plain enough: Genesis 1 mentions the creation of man as the last of a series, and without any details, whereas in Genesis 2 man is the centre of interest and more specific details are given about him and his setting. There is no incompatible duplication here at all. Failure to recognize the complementary nature of the subject-distinction between a skeleton outline of all creation on the one hand, and the concentration in detail on man and his immediate environment on the other, borders on obscurantism (1966, pp. 116-117, emp. in orig.).
 
 Apologetics Press - Are There Two Creation Accounts in Genesis?
 
 As for Cain finding a wife elsewhere, that isn't what the Bible says.
 
 Some claim that the passage in Genesis 4:16-17 means that Cain went to the land of Nod and found a wife. Thus, they can conclude there must have been another race of people on the earth, who were not descendants of Adam, who produced Cain's wife.
 
 “And Cain went out from the presence of the Lord, and dwelt in the land of Nod, on the east of Eden. And Cain knew his wife; and she conceived, and bore Enoch: and he built a city, and he called the name of the city, after the name of his son, Enoch.”
 
 From what has been stated previously, it is clear that all humans, Cain's wife included, are descendants of Adam. However, this passage does not say that Cain went to the land of Nod and found a wife. John Calvin, commenting on these verses, states:
 
 “From the context we may gather that Cain, before he slew his brother, had married a wife; otherwise Moses would now have related something respecting his marriage.”[13]
 
 Cain was married before he went to the land of Nod. He didn't find a wife there, but “knew” (had sexual relations with) his wife.[14]
 
 Where did Cain get his wife? - ChristianAnswers.Net
 
 You really need to study the Bible instead of butchering it. Your superficial expectoration of it is clearly sophomoric.

 The problem in arguing Biblical accuracy with a Biblical literalist is, they argue backwards.
 
 That is, they start with an a prior commitment to the Bible's "absolute truth." They then seek an interpretation that is consistent with this, and they are willing to resort to any number of contortions to accomplish it.
 
 So, for example, the Hebrew term "yatsar" (in Genesis 2) just has to be understood in the pluperfect ("had formed"), rather than the past ("formed"), because this allows them to preserve the conclusion that they've already got. Never mind that the Hebrew is in fact ambiguous.
 
 Or the more general claim that God's creation is good is allowed to "entail" (speaking loosely) the far more specific claim that Adam and Eve's DNA was without any corruptions, so that such can be attributed to the Fall, so that there's no problem with sleeping your sister early on, so that Cain's wife is explained without moral queasiness that might upset the notion of literal interpretation.
 
 So that's the strategy: start with the conclusion, and work backwards to find something consistent with it. It's hard to beat, not because this is a good strategy, or even because consistency is gained. It's hard to beat because when somebody's convinced of the truth beforehand, whatever they're doing, they're not actually having a good faith argument about it.
